title: Modern Irish Literature
requirement_sentence: This course will explore the overlay of language and politics on an island where even what you call a place is it the North of Ireland or Northern Ireland? implies a political stance. You will learn how writers of fiction, plays, and poetry have not only imagined but contributed to cultural and political phenomena from the Irish Revival and the Easter Rising through the Troubles and the peace process. Focusing on Irish literature in English, you will also read some Irish-language literature in translation. Writers are likely to include, among others, Lady Gregory, W. B. Yeats, James Joyce, Seamus Heaney, Nuala NÃ­ Dhomhnaill, and Anna Burns. Expect to read attentively, engage in class discussion, complete a brief in-class reading response or reading quiz each week, practice close reading in essay form, and develop a final project based in the splendid archives and manuscript collections of the Rose Library. Post 1900 Diverse Perspectives II

title: Studies In Women's Fiction: Dystopias--Hers and His
requirement_sentence: Dystopian novels have been so prominent in recent fiction that critics have described our time as a golden age for the genre. The result has been that, as one writer puts it, "there's a book for every type of modern dread." Particularly notable in this current dystopic outpouring has been the influence of women writers. This course juxtaposes the most famous dystopia written in English, George Orwell's 1984, with novels by contemporary women writers (Ling Ma, Octavia Butler, Margaret Atwood, and one TBA) to explore how their works are reshaping the genre. The imaginative societies envisioned by these writers pose crucial questions about where the real dangers lie for our future and our present through their groundbreaking dystopic novels. Requirements are active & informed class participation; occasional response paragraphs; 2 short papers, one potentially optional. Post 1900 Diverse Perspectives II Prose

title: Spec Studies in Classical Culture: Tragic Heroines
requirement_sentence: (Same as ITAL 375W 1, CPLT 389W 1, and WGS 385W 2) (Complete Topic - Tragic Heroines: Writing Women Across the Centuries) (This seminar will examine the role that women have played in the process of writing tragedy and how they have come to be viewed as the bearers of tragic pathos from classical antiquity to the Renaissance. The classical tragic figure could be either male or female, but the Renaissance ushers in new gender roles and modes of viewing that significantly alter this paradigm. In this class, we will explore the causes and effects of female subjectivity, agency, and sexuality beginning with Sophocles Antigone in 441 BCE and until the publication of Valeria Maini's lesbian-centered heroine, Celinda, published in 1611 CE. We will also focus on numerous theoretical texts that deal with the aesthetics of tragedy, all authored by men, to see how tragedy became a vehicle to challenge and question prevailing civic structures through the gendered lens of writing the tragic, female experience. Texts to be read may include a selection: Sophocles - Antigone Euripides - Alcestis Euripedes - Medea Seneca -Thyestes Gian Giorgio Trissino - Sofonisba Giambattista Giraldi Cinzio - Orbecche Sperone Speroni - Canace Torquato Tasso - Aminta and Re Torrismondo Aristotle - Poetics Horace - Ars Poetica Salvatore Di Maria - The Italian Tragedy in the Renaissance Freud - The Interpretation of Dreams and Beyond the Pleasure Principle Lacan - Seminar VII: The Ethics of Psychoanalysis)

title: Criticism: Read, Think, Write!
requirement_sentence: (Topic:Read, Think, Write! Intro. to Literary Theory and Criticism) (In read, think, write we will study the various ways in which scholars of literature instruct their readers on how to interpret literature, argue about its value, and the role it plays in society. Learning about each of the theoretical frameworks will allow you to not only learn about the ways scholars have tried to interpret texts, but also to critically read literature using the methods they have developed. We will address questions such as: how to read a literary text from a Feminist, Queer, Marxist or post-colonial perspective? We will learn about how these schools of thought emerged, some of the most prominent theorists, and the central questions they ask when critically analyzing a text. Student will choose literary pieces to perform different styles of critical interpretations from different literary theories. The goal is to provide you with a foundation for understanding how literature is discussed in scholarly and critical discourse.) Required Texts: -Vincent Leitch, et.al. The Norton Anthology of Theory and Criticism -Wesley Brown and Amy Ling, Imagining America.

title: Seminar in Poetry:English: Contemporary American Poetry
requirement_sentence: This seminar will survey major poets, schools and movements that make up the canon of Contemporary American Poetry in conversation with emerging voices from the present. Special attention will be devoted to the Black Aesthetic, the Beat generation, feminist poetics, and recent verse of LGBTQIA+ and new social movements. In addition, the course will afford students opportunities to pursue archival research working with manuscripts, correspondence, scrapbooks, rare editions, broadsides, and little magazines housed in Emory's Stuart A. Rose Manuscripts, Archives, and Rare Book Library.

title: Seminar in Fiction:English: Virginia Woolf & Her Contemp.
requirement_sentence: In her essay "How Should One Read a Book?" Virginia Woolf suggests that the best way to experience fiction is to drop all preconceived notions of what a novel can be: "do not dictate to your author; try to become him. Be his fellow-worker and his accomplice." In this course we will become the accomplices of one of the most inventive writers of twentieth-century literature. Reading our way through some of Woolf's major novels as well as selected essays, stories, and autobiographical writing, we will think about Woolf as a critic, humorist, feminist, and literary innovator, with special consideration to the way Woolf reinvents representations of character and human consciousness. While we focus on Woolf's illuminations of the interior self, we will also explore the adventurous artistic and philosophical spirit of Bloomsbury and how her work reflects England's transformation in the first half of the twentieth century: world war and its aftermath, changing social and sexual mores, new conceptions of gender roles and women's rights, advances in human psychology, and contemporaneous developments in painting and design. Texts may include some of the following: Woolf, Night and Day, Mrs. Dalloway, To the Lighthouse, Orlando, Between the Acts; The Waves; A Room of One's Own; Forster, Maurice; Bowen, The House in Paris; Mansfield, stories; Watson, Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day. Expectations: lively participation; weekly short Canvas postings; midterm and final essays.

title: Seminar in Criticism & Theory: Comparative Lit. Major Seminar
requirement_sentence: (Same as CPLT 490W 1) "How we Read, or the Scales of World Literature" This course is interested in reading practices and paradigms (such as close, distant, thematic, comparative, relational, contrapuntal, connective, transnational) that underpin world literature. And it addresses various conceptualizations of scale and scaling as a way of exploring the myriad relations and connections established between texts and communities in world literature. Scales that run from granular, local, minor, or regional frameworks to macro analyses like world-systems, connected histories, deep time, planetarity, and/or the digital humanities. As we engage with the question of scale, we'll take up important discussions in the field, like how well literature travels and on what basis, the many modes of text and textuality, the ethical implications of close versus distant reading practices, the risks of comparison, the significance of interpretative communities, the dialectic between literature and history, the problem of linguistic difference, and what is lost or gained in translation. Some of our primary readings, subject to change, include J.M. Coetzee, Diary of A Bad Year, Sabahattin Ali's Madonna in a Fur Coat, Hamid Ismailov's Gaia, Queen of Ants, and Amitav Ghosh's In An Antique Land.

title: Creative Writing: Intermediate Fiction
requirement_sentence: (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Application required. If accepted, YOU MUST ATTEND THE FIRST CLASS session to remain enrolled. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Please email nora.lewis@emory.edu if you have any questions. Inventing Time in Short Fiction This course expands craft concepts introduced in introductory creative writing coursework with a special focus on the narrative possibilities of time. How might we maintain a short story's necessary "intensity of focus" within a timeframe that spans centuries? How might a short story that takes place over the course of an hour give every detail heightened significance? In addition to exploring the narrative pressures of different timeframes, we will look at stories that break linearity, gesturing toward the future and even using elements like time travel to negotiate the constraints of the short story form. Selections from contemporary short fiction authors like Venita Blackburn, Sean Vestal, Mariah Rigg, Jonathan Escoffery, Brenda Peynado, Steven Millhauser, Ted Chiang, and Sofia Samatar will be included in our studies.

title: Creative Writing: Intermediate Poetry
requirement_sentence: (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Application required. If accepted, YOU MUST ATTEND THE FIRST CLASS session to remain enrolled. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Please email nora.lewis@emory.edu if you have any questions. FORMS In this intermediate course, you will find a community of poets serious about their craft, hoping to deepen their engagement with the art of poetry. Through the shared sense of trust and endeavor provided by the workshop community, we will closely read the work of published poets and that of our peers as we draft new poems ourselves. To structure our in-class discussions and the weekly creation of new work, we will look closely at prosody and the resurgence of traditional forms in the work of contemporary American poets. As we try out various forms ourselves, we will situate our own poetic experiments in a centuries-long conversation extending to our present moment.

title: Intermediate Playwriting
requirement_sentence: (Same as THEA 372RW 1) (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Application required. If accepted, you must attend the first class session to remain enrolled. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Please email nora.lewis@emory.edu if you have any questions. The instructor will be incoming Playwriting Fellow, PHANESIA PHAREL: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/people/bios/pharel-phan%C3%A9sia.html Application required. If accepted, you must attend the first class session to remain enrolled. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Plays are a human truth told in time. That truth is then brought to an audience to react, decide, reflect, and revolt. Plays are a singular democratic practice and gift in the human experience. Every single one of us has brilliant plays inside us, stories that connect others and help people feel alive, but how do we tell them? How do you figure out and access your truth - but more importantly, how can you make your truth legible to the outside world? In Intermediate Playwriting, we will be learning various elements of the craft, voyaging over a century worth of American playwrights to learn different tools and techniques, but more importantly for you to access what excites you and what themes you'd like your work to be in conversation with. In breaking down literary texts and exploring theatrical history, I often pose the central questions: What makes a play a play? What is theatricality? By investigating the foundations of story and identifying the elements that make a text theatrical, students develop a deeper understanding of both the craft and the medium. We will do this over a series of multiple exercises, and you will write a one-act play.

title: Creative Writing: Intermediate Non-Fiction
requirement_sentence: (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Application required. If accepted, YOU MUST ATTEND THE FIRST CLASS session to remain enrolled. Nonfiction Magazine and Long-form Writing. No pre-requisite. This class is NOT open to first-year students. This workshop is focused on long-form, nonfiction magazine and feature writing -- reading it, reporting it, writing it, and doing so in ways and by means that separate the exceptional from the pedestrian. This is nonfiction. Be prepared to be a reporter, to meet people face-to-face, to ask questions, to see and hear things with your own eyes and ears. My goal is to get your work published. We'll have visiting experts on hand as we discuss where great ideas come from, how to be strategic in your reporting, the art of the interview, and crafting stories, then stories within stories. We're looking mostly at print, but we will see beyond the dead tree media at the growing opportunities for magazine-style writing and long-form narratives online. Ultimately, the goal of the course is for you to become a considerably wiser and more effective nonfiction storyteller, for which the basis is sound reporting. Students should budget to purchase the textbook and for photocopying.

ger: Continuing Comm.& Writing with Race & Ethnicity(*)
requirement_sentence: Topic: Contagion and Crisis: Medical and Environmental Humanities This course surveys three centuries of epidemic literature, from the 1854 cholera outbreaks through contemporary pandemic narratives. Students will examine how literary and non-literary representations of contagion illuminate patterns of social inequality, environmental degradation, and systemic vulnerability. The course traces the evolution of disease narratives from the nineteenth-century urban crises to contemporary explorations of pandemic capitalism and bio-engineered plagues. Through critical analysis of texts spanning multiple historical periods, students will develop advanced skills in literary interpretation while engaging with urgent questions about environmental racism, global health disparities, and speculative futures in an era of interconnected crises.

title: Jr/Sr Coll: LatAm&NonWest Wrld: Partition of India, 1947
requirement_sentence: This course deals with the memory/history of the Partition of British India in 1947. This Partition resulted in the establishment of the nation-states of India, Pakistan and (in time) Bangladesh. The course investigates official and unofficial histories of this critical moment, when more than a million people died and over ten million became refugees in the subcontinent, and juxtaposes them with the memories of people who lived through the times. It lays emphasis on close reading and discussion to develop a critical approach to the understanding of modern societies and contested versions of history. We examine views of the past and the present that emerge in the new nation-states through a variety of primary and secondary sources, focusing on (1) official and academic histories, media, fiction and films; (2) oral accounts reflecting the new identities and perspectives of local groups, communities and regions, divided as these are by gender, caste and class.

title: GA Civil Rights Cold Cases
requirement_sentence: (Same as AAS 387RW 1, AMST 387RW 1, HIST 387RW 1) (Permission Required Prior to Enrollment) Application required. If accepted, you must attend the first class session to remain enrolled. Class description and application form are available on the Creative Writing Program website: https://creativewriting.emory.edu/academics/applications.html Please email nora.lewis@emory.edu if you have any questions. In the years between 1945 and 1968, untold numbers of American citizens were targeted for death because of their race, beliefs, or civil rights work - and in some cases merely because of what they drove, how they spoke, or the ever-shifting lines of racial etiquette they crossed. In many cases, their murders were inadequately investigated or prosecuted, their stories left untold, and the crimes against their humanity never punished. The Georgia Civil Rights Cold Cases Project at Emory University is both a class and an ongoing historical and journalistic exploration of the Jim Crow South through the prism of unsolved or unpunished civil rights-era murders in Georgia. Using primary evidence including FBI records, NAACP files, old newspaper clippings, court transcripts, and personal archives students come to see and understand history from the inside out. Student essays, grounded in secondary readings that provide broader context, will be aimed at the project website, coldcases.emory.edu. Students also may become engaged in helping research a new season of the podcast, Buried Truths, based on a case we'll be examining in class. Students should budget for photocopying.

title: ORDER Seminar: What Does it Mean to be Human?
requirement_sentence: Through an interdisciplinary exploration combining social sciences, sciences, and humanities disciplines and methodologies, we will engage in creative and intellectually rigorous conversation about the human experience, while writing our own stories in the process. This course will progress through separate topical units centered around three core questions: -How do we understand ourselves? Why is it difficult to define what is human? Why do we need to think of humanity as a problem? -Human compared to what? Here we seek to further illustrate what makes humanity distinct through a comparative lens. What is a human compared to an animal, a robot, or even, considering our strange relationship to the nation-state, a citizen? In doing this, we will think deeply about how humanity defines itself through and against its own narratives of power and dominance. -Where are we going? In addressing this question, we will attempt to work through some of the largest existential threats to humankind and determine two things: How do different disciplines tackle these issues? And can these disciplines work together to solve them?

title: Ethics: Buddhist Ethics
requirement_sentence: (Same as PHIL 385W 1) (This course satisfies the Religion major requirement: - Tradition-Buddhism, Theme.) (This writing-intensive seminar takes a broadly philosophical approach to the study of Buddhist understandings of the nature of goodness and how goodness can be recognized and cultivated. Materials for the course will range from Buddhist scriptures, to philosophical treatises, to narratives, to poetry, and to films. The intention of the course is to engage seriously with Buddhist understandings of the nature of the human condition as infused with suffering, and how humans can nevertheless develop goodness and resilience within this fleeting and unstable world. Topics include the extent and limits of generosity, the proper objects of loving-kindness and compassion, the moral consequences of truths and falsehoods, and mind-training techniques for taking obstacles as the path.) (Writing assignments will be weekly and will emphasize engagement with the course materials. There will be a final written project that builds on the work done during the semester.)

title: Special Topics in Religion: Howard Thurman & Community
ger: Continuing Comm.& Writing with Race & Ethnicity(*)
requirement_sentence: No pre-requisite required. This course explores the contributions of the theologian, mystic, and often-overlooked Civil Rights hero Howard Thurman on how people can work to establish, build, and extend community. Thurman, who led the first African Americans to meet with Gandhi in India, was a mentor to many Civil Rights leaders, and his classic book, Jesus and the Disinherited, served as an inspiration to them. After an examination of Thurman's life and thought, the course will focus on his interpretations of Jesus's Prodigal Son and Good Samaritan parables, because they illustrate Thurman's understanding of how to (re)establish community. In brief, Thurman's mysticism, its relationship with social change, and his practice of using the fine arts to raise one's spiritual consciousness and foster community, encourage a "sympathetic understanding" of other human beings.

title: Studies in Music History and Culture: Singing the Sacred
requirement_sentence: Class will meet at CST 368. The purpose of this course is to provide a survey of sacred song during the past five centuries, making use of the rare items in Special Collections at Pitts Theology Library. Pitts holds one of the most extensive and diverse collections of psalmody and hymnody in the world. In some cases, a particular volume in Pitts is the only extant copy in North America, and sometimes it is the only one to be found anywhere.
